abstract: Supreme Court throws out conviction of Florida fisherman John L Yates for tossing evidence, 72 undersize grouper, back into Gulf of Mexico in 2007 after receiving citation from a Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission officer; ruling from Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg determines fish are not tangible objects as defined by Sarbanes-Oxley Act, federal law aimed mostly at white-collar crime.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decided that grouper thrown back into the Gulf of Mexico did not meet the definition of a tangible object specified in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

headline.main: In Overturning Conviction, Supreme Court Says Fish Are Not Always Tangible
headline.print_headline: In Overturning Conviction, Supreme Court Says Fish Are Not Always Tangible

snippet: The Supreme Court decided that grouper thrown back into the Gulf of Mexico did not meet the definition of a tangible object specified in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
